event_text: Geology: Gold mineralisation is related to the development of shear zones and quartz veins focused along a mafic - felsic contact with historical shafts and workings located over approximately 500 metres of strike. The Sabbath deposit is an Achaean aged gold deposit located approximately 15 kilometres north of Meekatharra in Western Australia. Gold mineralisation is related to the development of shear zones and quartz veins focused along a mafic - felsic contact with historical shafts and workings located over approximately 500 metres of strike. During the last four years Au Mining has spent in excess of $170,000 conducting drilling and prefeasibility activities and in that time has conducted systematic drilling and earthsawing over approximately 400 metres of strike length which has defined a JORC compliant indicted resource of 145,000 t @ 2.52 g/t Au, located within 50 metres of the surface. Some of the more significant intersections returned included 8m @ 15.92 g/t Au and 16m @ 4.28 g/t Au, with a number of intersections requiring follow up drilling with mineralization open at depth.

event_text: Lithologies are predominantly metamorphosed to amphibolite facies; however there are remnants of unaltered basalts and sediments in the more central portions of the belt. The mafic volcanics are thought to belong to the Warrawoona Group; the clastic sediments are tentatively assigned to the Corboy Formation and the BIFs and cherts to the Cleaverville Formation. The prospective Cleaverville Formation usually occurs near the centre, sitting on older Warrawoona Group volcano-sediments, which occupy the flanks near the granites. Cleaverville Formation sediments occupy a complex central position between the outer amphibolites and the three inner bodies of maficultramafics and sit unconformably on the Warrawoona Group over most of the area, but are interpreted to overlie Corboy Formation sediments in the south. They are dominated by fine-grained sediments, which include siltstones, interbedded siltstones and cherts, BIFs and bedded cherts.

event_text: This licence formed part of a much larger group of tenement which was explored from 1976 onwards by the Ashton Exploration JV which led to the discovery of several kimberlite dykes along the western edge of the Halls Creek Mobile Belt including the Argyle Pipe. This work initially comprised a regional drainage sampling followed up later by additional sampling and aeromagnetic surveys. Two magnetic anomalies (DUN07 and DUN08) within E80/2294 were identified as having the potential to be caused by diamondiferous diatremes. Follow-up gravity surveys did not reveal a characteristic low typical of a concealed kimberlite pipe. However, loam samples collected at both anomalies tested positive for kimberlitic indicator minerals and the chemistry of the chromite grains from DUN08 was typical of a kimberlitic/lamproitic source.

event_text: This coincides with an increasing number of igneous intrusions and quartz veins towards the east. The appearance of chlorite, biotite and finally garnet has been observed from west to east within E70/2237, and is consistent with a Barrovian-type metamorphic Page 11 of 17 October 2008 sequence, where temperature increased into amphibolite facies towards the intrusions to the east. The presence of well preserved actinolite appears to be the result of retrograde metamorphism through greenschist facies. Finally, towards the eastern edge of the tenement, the quartzite adopts a gneissic texture, indicative of high grade metamorphic conditions. event_text: The population at Weld Range is considered significant as it lies at the northern extreme of the species range and appears to be isolated restricted to the slopes and valleys associated with the Weld Range. During correspondence with Atlas, the Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) has requested: the proponent undertake a habitat risk assessment and targeted surveys for SRE [Short Range Endemic] fauna, particularly Idiosoma nigrum to verify the presence of significant species in proximity to (within 200m of) proposed drilling or other disturbances. Significant fauna species include species that are listed under legislation or as Priority by the Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC), but also includes species that are known or suspected of having a restricted distribution; referred to as Short Range Endemic (SRE). Areas such as the Weld Range are conducive to the evolution of SRE species, as the range provides relictual habitat in which such species can develop in isolation. SREs are common among invertebrate groups such as millipedes, land snails, pseudoscorpions, isopods (slaters) and scorpions.

event_text: 2.1 Regional Geology Yalgoo The two main greenstone sequences of the Murchison Province are both present in the Yalgoo Greenstone Belt. These are the Luke Creek Group and the Mount Farmer Group. The Luke Creek Group consists of laterally extensive (province-wide) lava plains, banded iron formations (BIF) and associated rocks. The Mount Farmer group consists of nine distinct volcanic centres and one sedimentary basin (Watkins and Hickman, 1990). The Luke Creek Group is the older of the two and includes the Murrouli Basalt, the Golconda, Gabanintha and Windaning Formations.

event_text: Workings and prospecting pits are scarce to non-existent in outcropping areas throughout the district, suggesting either that the sequences are not well mineralized or that historical activity was limited by the remoteness and lack of surface water supplies. A major mineralized shear zone, the Aldiss Fault, is situated to the northwest of the project area, some 5km east of the inferred Terrane boundary interpreted to coincide with the Roe Hills Fault. The Aldiss Fault is not particularly conspicuous as an aeromagnetic 8 C21/2007 Woodline Project Annual Report for the period 1 Jan to 31 Dec 2008 CR34109 Newmont Exploration Pty Ltd feature, but it is the controlling structure for the significant Karonie-French Kiss line of prospects, which are currently under advanced exploration by Integra Mining Ltd. It is not clear where (or if) the Aldiss and Roe Hills Faults continue to the south beyond a zone of disruption along the Binneringie Dyke and the main depositional centre of the Proterozoic Woodline Formation. Although the Project area is on the margins of the Yilgarn Craton and in some cases close to major granite intrusive bodies, metamorphic grade in the greenstone belts is markedly low to the north and west of the Cundeelee Fault, being predominantly lower greenschist facies.

event_text: In general, the areas (mesas) of Robe Pisolite were found to be surrounded by outcrops of Proterozoic basement (basalt and sometimes sediment) implying the pisolite outcrops were simply weathered remnants of channel iron accumulations that had probably been eroded and washed further down the drainage. In both the Panhandle and Airport prospects assays from the pisolites that were sampled reported Fe assays in excess of 50% but with relatively high silica (4 to 10%) and Al2O3 (4 to 8%) reflecting the weathered nature of the samples. At the Panhandle prospect, coarse grain sizes and wood fragments in excess of 1 cm in size were common, suggesting proximity to the basal section of the channel. This could also be inferred from the outcrop mapping which found significant amounts of basaltic outcrop nearby negating the possibility of a large channel being present. At the Airport prospect, the pisolite outcrops were found along the margins of Bellary Creek which is thought to have eroded away the channel iron mineralization leaving only remnants as evidence of prior channel iron accumulations.

event_text: INTRODUCTION This report outlines the mineral exploration activities carried out over the tenement group C73/2008, which comprised tenements E70/2801 and E70/3000, between 12 March 2009 and 11 March 2010 for the Rocky Gully Project. The primary target in the area was nickelcopper sulphide mineralisation. Herons work indicated that the geology and mineralisation of the project area share similarities with those of the NeboBabel (Musgrave region), Voiseys Bay (Canada), Thunder Bay North (Canada), Talnakh (Norilsk, Siberia) and Santa Rita (Brazil) massive sulphide nickel deposits. Such chonolithconduit mineralisation models have not yet been tested within the AlbanyFraser Orogen. Much of the project area is freehold land.

event_text: Early stage resource estimates based on wide spaced drilling can be expected to underestimate grade as has been the case for the Bulchina, Lord Henry and Lord Nelson deposits mined by Troy. In Snowdens experience, it is not cost effective at the resource definition stage to drill at a sufficiently close spacing to model the full complexity of vein hosted mineralisation. It is recommended, instead, that a change of support method and/or conditional simulation is used to develop recoverable resource models (less tonnes at higher grade than the bulk block model approach) for future resource estimates, reducing the possibility of overlooking potentially economic resources. event_text: Dyke margins and D2 shears acted as pre-existing weaknesses, with those of a northeast or northwest trend being preferentially re-activated as either dextral or sinistral shears, respectively, as a result of increasing fluid pressure in a strike-slip regime thus producing shear vein lodes. North-northwest to north trending, steep-dipping diorite dykes and D2 faults formed extension vein lodes as a result of increasing fluid pressure and north/northwest-south/southeast extension, resulting in vertical release of fluids and pressure in the process. event_text: The Wiluna Greenstone Belt can be divided into two metamorphic domains, the Wiluna domain in the east and the Matilda domain in the west. The major north west trending Perseverance Fault (also known as the Erawalla Fault) separates the domains. The Wiluna domain is a low grade, prehnite-pumpellyite facies, metamorphic terrain comprising mafic to ultramafic lavas with intercalated sedimentary units, felsic volcanics and dolerite sills overlain by a thick pile of felsic volcanics, tuffaceous sediments, and sedimentary rocks, interrupted by extrusion of a large volume of komatiitic lava. Primary igneous textures and structures are well preserved, and deformation is predominantly brittle. The Matilda domain is a medium to high grade, greenschist to lower amphibolite facies, metamorphic terrain with predominantly ductile deformation.

event_text: 3.0 INTRODUCTION 3.1 Preamble Fimiston Mining discovered Apollo Hill in December 1986, during a drill program aimed at finding the source of abundant alluvial gold at the base of a prominent hill in the area. Multiple gold mineralization events have occurred at Apollo Hill during a complex deformational history. Gold mineralization is accompanied by quartz veins and carbonate-pyrite alteration associated with a mafic-felsic contact. event_text: The district experiences a dry tropical climate, with a wet humid summer from October to April and a cool dry winter during May to September. event_text: The licence area is accessed by road from Perth by following the Great Northern Highway to Cue, some 650km northeast of Perth, and then following the unsealed north-westerly Cue to Beringarra Road for some 180km to a point where the road crosses the Jack Hills towards their south-western end (this road also traverses Midwests Weld Range Project just to the south of Madoonga Station). The main area of iron ore mineralisation is then reached by a track towards the northeast along the northern side of the ranges for some 15km, or to the south west along a station track along the southern side of the ranges for some 10 km (Figure 1) (total distance from Perth about 850km). event_text: Page 5 At the Yarbu North target (Figure 14), auger soil sampling defined two extensive areas of strongly anomalous gold in soils (Andromeda North and Andromeda South). Reconnaissance RAB drilling of Andromeda North returned several plus g/t gold intersections requiring follow-up RAB drilling. Widely spaced reconnaissance auger soil sampling along the inferred position of the Clampton Shear Zone (CSZ) within E77/864 (Figures 15 - 18), returned anomalous gold results up to 746 ppb, warranting follow-up infill soil sampling followed by RAB drilling. A single RAB drill traverse testing a discrete aeromagnetic high along the CSZ returned anomalous gold, suggesting that aeromagnetic highs are high priority targets for follow-up RAB drilling.  Reconnaissance RAB drilling of the Sandplain soil gold target area has established the presence of widespread anomalous to low grade gold mineralisation hosted by extensively altered Diemals Formation sediments and ultramafics.

event_text: Cavities are interpreted to have formed by hydrothermal karsting. Mineralisation is localised at the regional dolomite front, which is partly controlled by the transition from platform to reef carbonates. Mineralisation also shows a strong structural control, concentrated along N-trending structural corridors. Displacement is minor, and mineralisation occurs in dissolution breccias around the corridors rather than within discrete structures. At Kutarta, disseminated low-grade replacive mineralisation forms a broad zone in the hangingwall of the Cadjebut Fault, extending away from the fault as stratabound zones within favourable reefal and fenestral units.

event_text: Coal exploration began in earnest in the Fitzroy Trough in 1965 and continued into the early 1980s. Drilling carried out by Blackfin PL in 2005 on an area centred on the Petaluma #1 petroleum well on the Deep Well Anticline, 40 kilometres northeast of E04/1520, confirmed the presence of a thick coal seam (approximately 14 metres) at depths below 200 metres. 4 Figure 3: Tenement Geology Interpretation 5 In 2009, a JORC-compliant resource of 511 million tonnes of thermal coal was announced for the Paradise and Duchess Coal Deposits, 70 kilometres northeast of E04/1520. event_text: It lies at the convergence of Australias main Proterozoic structural trends that reflect the amalgamation of the North, West, and South Australian Cratons (Smithies, 2013). Within the West Musgrave province the nature and age of the basement is poorly constrained with intrusive components as old as c.1600 Ma and banded gneiss dominated by material derived from volcanic, volcanoclastics and sedimentary protoliths (Smithies, 2008). The 1335-1295 Ma Mount West Orogeny and 1220-1155 Ma Musgravian Orogeny are major crustal events that involved intrusion of early I-type Warakurna Supersuite and later A-type Pitjantjara Supersuite granites, high-grade crustal reworking, intensive deformation, and widespread ultra-high temperature metamorphism (Smithies, 2008). The Ngaanyatjarra Rift is the main structural expression of the Mesoproterozoic Giles Event which saw the earlier Mesoproterozoic rocks of the Musgrave Province extensively intruded and covered by bimodal magmatic rocks of the Warakurna Supersuite. Volcanic rocks of the Warakurna Supersuite (Bentley Supergroup) are the dominant component of the Bentley Basin the fill of the Ngaanyatjarra Rift.

event_text: Overall, most geochronological data point to an age of circa 1800 Ma for late (D5) gold in the Tanami region. The age of the apparently earlier gold event (D1 or D3 at The Granites) is not constrained (Huston et al., in prep). Bagas and Huston (2005) suggest that gold mineralisation at the Kookaburra and Sandpiper deposits in the Bald Hill area occurred during c.1790Ma during the Tanami Orogeny and broadly coeval with the emplacement of granites. They suggest that the gold-bearing quartz veins were emplaced throughout the northeast-southwest compressional DB2 folding and faulting episode as saddle reefs and along bedding contacts, on the subvertical fold axes, and as cross-cutting subhorizontal sheets. It has been suggested that gold mineralisation at Coyote occurred during a DB3 east-west compression, when DB2 faults and folds were opened up to allow fluid ponding and mineralisation (L. Note that it is likely that the average P content of Pilbara ores will increase with time, potentially making the above materials increasingly attractive for blending purposes. The current depletion in the Pilbara Iron resource base at Paraburdoo coupled with the possible supply of a significant amount of lump material from the Ashburton Project, should lead to an increase in interest by Pilbara Iron. event_text: Visual checks of the flight paths were conducted in Mapinfo. Each RepTEM Survey Profile and Conductivity line flown was then overlayed on top of the flight path, (Figure 1). Using both the graphic data produced for each line it was possible to work out where there were areas of low conductivity and areas of high conductivity, which would in turn indicate where there are areas of basement highs and basement lows, or channel-hosted saline aquifers. 12 Where there are Basement highs are generally associated with relatively low conductivity, while basement lows (channels) are usually associated with relatively high levels of conductivity. We used a progressive approach to divide the information up; these were basement, channel and a transition layer from channel to basement, (Figure 3).

event_text: In a CAMIRO study using Pb isotopes the mobile metal ions were proved to have been transported from deeply-buried ore bodies to the surface. The theory behind MMI is that a buried ore body through physical (e.g. capillary rise) and electrochemical processes frees mobile metal ions, which are migrating to the 8 surface where they are weakly attached to soil particles. These mobile metal ions are sampled by the MMI technique. Their mobility is subsequently restricted by different processes resulting in them being permanently bound to the soil particles.

event_text: It was considered that although the tenement was host to coal measures within the northern portion of the tenement these coal-bearing sediments were at depths greater than 350m from surface. These depths were considered economically unattractive as an exploration target and as a consequence no further work was recommended and the northern portion of the tenement comprising 38 blocks was recommended for relinquishment. The Fitzroy Trough occurs as a generally NW-SE trending sub-basin within the broader Canning Basin. The Trough is unconformably bounded along its NE margin by the older Lennard Shelf Precambrian to Ordovician units. Along its SW margin the Trough is separated from the dominantly Jurassic stratigraphy of the Broome Arch by the Fenton Fault System (Figure 3).

event_text: D2: Main deformation forming granitoid domes and greenstone synclines caused by diapiric intrusion of granitoids during the deposition of the early Warrawoona Group and continuing to the end of the deposition of the Georg Creek Group. D3: Conjugate folding and faulting associated with east-west compression. D4: Tight to open folding in some parts of the Pilbara with uncertain relationship to other events. The metamorphic grade in the Goldsworthy and Ord Ranges are uniformly greenschist facies with lithologies preserved across the separating Pardoo Fault. event_text: Exploration for uranium in the granite sequence has been minimal, and there has been only cursory investigation of other channels within the valley. In 1970, regional radiometric surveys defined a large and intense anomaly in the Yeelirrie Valley drainage system. Shallow auger drilling by Western Mining Corporation in 1971 showed a large body of carnotite mineralisation hosted by calcrete. Over the subsequent 12 years, over 6,000 drill holes comprising reverse circulation (RC) and diamond drilling defined a sizeable resource of 35 Mt of 0.15% U3O8, for 52,500 t of U3O8. Permission to mine was refused under the three mines policy which limited uranium exports during the 1980s.
label: False

event_text: Altona-Cosmopolitan: A significant number of old workings lie along the Altona trend, which strikes north-south and dips -50o to the east. It is parallel to similar structures at Cosmopolitan to the west and the Champion deposits to the northwest and all appear to be high angle reverse faults with steeply plunging ore shoots. All three deposits lie within a north to northeast trending corridor of mineralisation that defines the Kookynie mining centre and occur along structures of significant strike extent, up to 2.5km in the case of the Champion Trend. The magnetic interpretation suggests these three deposits and the Puzzle deposit may all lie within or along the contact of the same granite body although there is a significant degree of extrapolation under cover. The radiometric data indicates the granite is potassium rich and this may in part reflect an alteration phenomena (sericite/K fsp).
label: False

event_text: The Siliciclastic Sequences are the youngest Archaean rocks and are predominantly turbidites but include carbonaceous shale, sandstone, conglomerate, chert and magnetic shale (BIF). A regional, four-stage, contractional deformation history has been constructed for the Eastern Goldfields (Morey, 2007): D1 - the earliest shortening event is characterised by a roughly NS directed thrusting and recumbent folding that resulted in large scale repetition of the greenstone sequences. D2 - a major stage of ENE-WSW shortening which gave rise to NNW trending, regional, upright folds and major reverse faulting/thrusting. This deformation episode was associated with multiple shortening episodes and intervening extensional stages. D3 - further ENE-WSW shortening reactivated NNW-trending D2 structures to produce dominantly sinistral strikeslip ductile faults.
label: False

event_text: An idealised komatiite sheet flow stratigraphic succession in descending order is: gabbro (non cumulate) pyroxenite pyroxene cumulates (including harrisite) OOC olivine orthocumulate, thin heterogeneous units oMC olivine mesocumulate, upper oAC olivine adcumulate, thick uniform sheet flow sequence oMC basal olivine mesocumulate oOC basal thin unit olivine orthocumulate Textural interpretations are an important exploration guide, and are a prime basis for drillhole siting. Strong drilling results can be rapidly encountered through effective field interpretation of komatiite facies based on textural observations. Some sulphide mineralisation has been noted in the fresh ultramafics, but there does not appear to be any correlation between the sulphides and elevated nickel mineralisation within the ultramafics at depth. Drill log data indicates that the ultramafics consist of orthocumulate serpentinites and olivinites, while the granites contain lenses of felsic porphyry, and fine-grained diorites and rhyolites. The mafics consist of gabbro, dolerite and basalt.

event_text: The Emull base metal occurrence within the E80/2612 tenement area is hosted by altered and contact metamorphosed calc-silicate rocks, which have been partially assimilated by the Emull gabbro. The deposit was recognised as a series of copper stained, siliceous gossans located adjacent to the contact between the Emull gabbro and felsic volcanic rocks of the Koongie Park Formation. Thin semi-massive and disseminated mineralisation is confined to 4 discontinuous but apparently stratabound lenses, dominated by sphalerite, with subordinate chalcopyrite and galena. The largest lens has a strike length of 500m and a maximum width of 50m. The genesis of mineralisation at Emull is not certain, although models based on an origin as a volcanic hosted massive sulphide (VHMS) deposit partially assimilated during intrusion of gabbro, or as a skarn developed during intrusion of gabbro into carbonate units within the Koongie Park Formation, have been proposed.

event_text: Complications of Anomaly Interpretation In the grading process, small, discrete conductors were given a better grade than larger bodies, which were assumed to be lithological. Lithological conductors are generally formational (i.e. composed of a particular stratigraphic unit), with extended strike lengths, broader anomalies, and moderate to large electromagnetic responses. Often their conductivity is due to graphitic content rather than economic mineralisation. However the conclusion should not be drawn that larger conductors are definitely not mineralised.

event_text: The dykes range in thickness, being between 10 to 100 metres. h. FORTESCUE GROUP The weakly metamorphosed volcanic and sedimentary Neo Archean Fortescue Group is the most widespread supracrustal succession in the region. The succession is confined to the east along the western margin of the extensive northeast Pilbara Sub Basin of the Fortescue Basin. The Fortescue Group uncomformably overlies, or is faulted against, the Mount Edgar Granitic Complex, the Marble Bar, Kelly and McPhee Greenstone belts, and the Gorge Creek Group. The Black Range Dolerite Suite is considered to be part of the feeder dyke system for the Mount Roe Basalt.

event_text: The purpose of the drilling was to confirm the location of the palaeochannel as indicated by the gravity survey and then determine the stratigraphy and oxidation state of the sediments contained within it to provide a vector to those regions that contain sediments suitable to host uranium mineralisation. All holes were shallow, with depths ranging from 14- 24m, and the sediments intersected consisted of units of sand and sand clays with lesser amounts of gravel with the fill overlying a granite basement. The sediments were all oxidized with the extent of oxidation ranging from very weakly to strong, which is favourable for the uranium to remain dissolved in the ground water rather than for it to precipitate to form mineral deposits. Downhole gamma surveying was conducted on 2 aircore holes. The holes were cased with 50mm PVC casing as deep as possible before the hole became blocked and then the survey conducted to the depth of casing.

event_text: The ultramafic rocks are also less MgO-rich (as reflected in Ni content) in BMW1 compared to further west (Mt Jope Komatiite, BMW1 max 1200 ppm, to west 1400 ppm Ni: Suite 16, 950 ppm compared to 1310 ppm Ni). Mapping coupled with detailed aeromagnetic data has defined the geometry and lateral extent of the main units within the Fortescue Group around the Bellary Dome that have potential to host magmatic Ni-Cu-PGE sulphide mineralisation. These are the Mt Jope Komatiite, an olivine-rich channel-facies sequence within a komatiitic basalt flow, Suite 16, an extensive (>40 km strike) fractionated mafic/ultramafic sill with an olivine-rich ultramafic zone up to 70 m thick, and several layered gabbrodominated sills with pyroxenitic basal zones. The komatiite flow is located in the lowest part of the Pyradie Formation whereas Suite 16 transgresses the lower Formations of the Fortescue Group particularly within a high-level feeder complex within a NW-trending fracture zone. One of the gabbro/pyroxenite sills also is markedly transgressive.

event_text: The RTP process simplifies the anomaly shape, thus improving the ability to accurately locate the causative source and more easily map the magnetic lithology (Figure 12b). First Vertical Derivative (1VD) This algorithm mathematically estimates the rate of fall off of the magnetic and or gravity field with height to remove the broad magnetic/gravity field that is created with a body. Its effect is to sharpen the edges of anomalies and to suppress broad anomalies associated with deeper sources (Figure 12d). Second Vertical Derivative (2VD) The second vertical derivative uses a mathematical algorithm to change the rate of fall of the either the magnetic or gravity field with height to remove the broad magnetic/gravity field that is created with a body. Its effect is to further sharpen the edges of anomalies and to suppress broad anomalies associated with deeper sources (Figure 12e).

event_text: The hydrothermal fluid was a H2O-CO2-S-metal bearing fluid, as supported by the nature of fluid inclusions in veins and in sealed microcracks in preserved quartz phenocrysts in wallrock, and by the sericite-carbonate-sulphide-bearing nature of the alteration assemblage. The inferred fluid composition is typical of lode-gold systems, and is inferred to have been sourced externally from the observed porphyries. The pale yellow colour of the strongly altered rocks is entirely attributable to sericite; epidote is absent from all of the alteration assemblages because it is unstable in the presence of even small amounts of CO2-bearing hydrothermal fluid. Early hematite-bearing alteration affected the porphyries (sample WHD003, 118.6m). Relict hematite occurs in ovoid to cuspate patches, now overprinted by the reduced sericite-pyrite-bearing Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3156 -4- Placer Dome Kalgoorlie Exploration mineralising assemblage.

event_text: Newcrest suggested the turbidite sediments are mostly unaltered but this is questionable given the intensity of the alteration of the neighbouring rock types. Types of porphyritic granitoid intruding the Hobbes volcanic sequence include quartz monzonite, monzonite, quartz monzodiorite, rhyodacitic porphyry and highly altered (biotite-epidote-sericite) porphyritic mafic granitoids that are possibly diorites. Some are foliated with an anastomosing schistose 9 fabric defined by sericite alteration. event_text: Felsic dykes become more abundant in the south east of the tenement. The felsic intrusives are interpreted to be synchronous with tectonism and mineralisation, as they often intrude along zones of shearing and mineralisation. event_text: The fine-grained sandstone units may display softsediment deformation structures. The coarser upper units feature up to 60 metres of stacked, upward fining cycles. Important diagnostics are considered to be firstly, the predominance of sandstone and the absence of coal seams of significant thickness and areal extent and secondly, a carbonaceous content in the subordinate dark-grey to black siltstone and mudstone units. The basal contact of the cycle may be erosional and associated with intraformational conglomerate characteristics by rip-up clasts of siltstone and infrequent macerated carbonaceous detritus. The Westralia Sandstone can be correlated with equivalent units in the Collie, Boyup and southern Perth Basins Ewington Coal Measures: The Ewington Coal Measures are the most areally extensive coal-bearing unit in the basin and can be correlated across the whole coalfield and into adjacent basins including the Perth Basin.

event_text: Uplift accompanied by extensive erosion and weathering took place from Late Cretaceous through the Tertiary in the Perth Basin. Numerous marine incursions occurred during the Late Tertiary to Pleistocene period that eroded a marine platform extending inland for a distance of around 30km to the Darling and Whicher Scarps. Unconformably overlying the Cretaceous Leederville Formation in the Southern Perth Basin is a paralic sequence of marine-estuarine, beach and dune deposits, locally enriched in heavy mineral sands and known as the Yoganup Formation. This is variably overlain to the west by the Guilford Formation and by later alluvial fan deposits and thin aeolian quartz and calcarenite dunes of the Bassendean, Spearwood and Quindalup dune systems. There have been numerous phases of HM accumulation, ascribed broadly to the Capel (0-10m RL) and the Yoganup (20-80m RL) palaeo-shorelines.

event_text: Some of the larger D2 folds are thought to have been re-orientated during D3, from an original N-S trend, into trends more closely aligned with the D3 shear zones (e.g. Bungalbin synform and Broadbents antiform; Fig. Metamorphic grade in the supracrustal rocks of the central Southern Cross Domain ranges from very low to low grade in the interior of the larger greenstone belts, through to medium to high grade along the margins of the larger belts, and across the full width of some of the narrower greenstone belts 4 (Ahmat 1986; Chen and Wyche 2001). Metamorphism is thought to have spanned the duration of D2 and D3, and coincided with the main period of granitoid emplacement, between 2700 and 2640 Ma. event_text: The oldest unit recorded from E04/2151 is the Late Devonian (Famennian), Windjana Limestone which, along with the overlying Nullara Limestone, forms the major cliffs of the Oscar Range. The Devonian reef complex within the Oscar Range area has been extensively studied and is described in Playford and Lowry (1966). Extensive outcrops of the Early Carboniferous, Gumhole Formation and Fairfield Formation are mapped to the north of the limestone cliffs. Within the tenement, limestones, dolomites and a variety of clastic sedimentary lithologies have been encountered in shallow drilling and pitting. event_text: The greenstone belt corresponds to the western most subdivision of the extensive north-northwest trending Norseman-Wiluna Greenstone Belt and covers a total strike extent of approximately 150km. The Ularring Greenstone Belt occupies an extensive sequence of mafic and ultramafic rocks with interbedded volcanogenic sediments and felsic to intermediate volcanics. The geology is structurally complex, consisting of cross cutting and regional shear zones, a regional antiformsynform-antiform sequence (in the southern hinge region at Mt Ida), reverse faulting, extensive deformation, intrusive porphyries and basal ultramafic contacts (see figure 2). The Ida structural corridor, incorporating the Ida Shear Zone, represents an extensive regional lineament that has been recognised over a distance of 500km. The regional structural feature juxtaposes the Kalgoorlie Terrane from the Southern Cross Terrane and incorporates the Ularring Greenstone Belt (figure 3.1.1 1).

event_text: Hunter (1993) correlated a number of the Coolgardie units with volcano-stratigraphy at Ora Banda, Kalgoorlie and Kambalda. Standing (2001) makes the case that much of the volcano-stratigraphy in the Kalgoorlie Terrane and particularly in the Coolgardie area, although well mapped, has been supported by only very limited petrography, whole-rock and trace element geochemical data and even less rare earth element data. Therefore, Standing (2001) questions many of the traditional correlations that have been made for the different regions but in particular for the Coolgardie area. Standing (2001) suggests that the stratigraphy at Coolgardie is unique relative to that in the centre of the Kalgoorlie Terrane or at Ora Banda, and as such he recommends the use of a local stratigraphic nomenclature (Figure 4). event_text: If a large data set that covers a variety of rock types (and may include variations in sampling techniques) is not split in some manner, then very high value (or values) will obscure any more subtle responses from other areas - say a very poorly exposed system with weak leakage compared to something that is readily seen and sampled. Page 5 Mathematical techniques such as used by Carras Mining do not initially require knowledge of specific field conditions and therefore can be applied to large data sets successfully. As the targets/anomalous groups show then application of field data (or need to collect more field data) becomes more critical. This has the ability to make more subtle targets visible/discreet and therefore they can then be more effectively explored. There are some cautions with some of the smaller or apparently "unusual" groups that can appear in any set (sometimes a function of too few samples etc) and also with elements that tend to only occur at around detection levels.

event_text: Overlying the Antrim Plateau Volcanics is the Goose Hole Group, consisting successively of the massive micritic Headleys Limestone with minor stromatolitic units, particularly near the base, the Nelson Shale which consists of carbonatic siltstones and mudstones and thin gypsum beds at numerous intervals, the richly fossiliferous Linnekar Limestone and the Panton Formation, consisting of siltstone and lesser arkosic sandstones and mudstones and minor limestones. These units form the Negri Subgroup of the Goose Hole Group and are overlain by the Elder Subgroup that consists of the Eaglehawk Sandstone, a marginal marine to fluvial fine feldspathic sandstone and minor siltstone, overlain by the Overland Sandstone, a clayey lithic arkose unit. Michigan Copper Belt USA-The Model The Michigan Copper belt on the Keweenaw Peninsula, Michigan USA has produced approximately 7 million tonnes of copper and significant silver. Copper mineralization consists of structurally controlled native copper dominated mineralization in fragmented and amygdaloidal basaltic rocks and interbedded coarse grained sediments of the Portage Lake Volcanics and stratabound mineralization in the overlying Nonesuch Shale. Mineralisation is a basin wide phenomenon, with the major deposits of native copper hosted by the Portage Lake Volcanics in the Calumet area (over 5 million tonnes Cu metal) separated by about 100 km from the lesser native copper deposits and the sulphidic White Pine deposit (approx 1.9 million tonnes Cu metal) in the Nonesuch Shale at White Pine.

event_text: Available evidence indicates that the sequence is broadly conformable and that it youngs consistently to the northeast, with steep dips commonly to the northeast. A static style of regional metamorphism of low greenschist facies is most common for the belt. However within the project area and along the western margin of the belt, the presence of metamorphic foliation and amphibolites indicates higher grade dynamic recrystallisation to middle-amphibolite facies. The belt is enclosed to the east, west and south by granitoids whose fabrics resemble those of the Western Gneiss Terrain. Less deformed granitoids intrude the older granitic Mt.Gibson Project - Combined Annual Report 2006 2 rocks and are believed to be responsible for the later, symmetrical, open cylindrical folding of the supracrustral rocks.

event_text: The project area covers the southern portion of the Woodie Woodie Manganese Corridor (WWMC); a north-south elongate domain of Archaean-Proterozoic sediments and mafic intrusions hosting numerous structurally and stratigraphically controlled Manganese deposits. The WWMC is on the eastern margin of the Hamersley Basin where the Archaean-Proterozoic Mt Bruce Supergroup is devoid of the Marra Mamba and Brockman Iron Formations which host numerous, large, high grade Iron Ore deposits to the south and west. The WWMC is bounded to the east by the Paterson Province a Proterozoic Mobile Belt hosting numerous structurally-controlled Au-Cu (Telfer), Cu (Nifty), U, PGE (Kintyre) deposits. Primary, epithermal mineralisation at Woodie Woodie is believed to have been Archaean in age, whereas secondary, supergene mineralisation is a much later Oligocene event.

event_text: Structural data from Landsat, Air Photo and Air Magnetic images were collated and transferred to a scale useful for understanding the tenement in detail. The tenements are situated over Proterozoic sedimentary formations with a dominant SW-NE strike orientation that have been folded around the flanks of the Goodin Dome. The Doolgunna Formation rocks have potential gold exploration targets related to the fault structures radial to the Goodin dome and also chert horizons associated with the intruded mafics. It is possible that planar faults, bedding plane faults, major rock contacts and areas where multiple fracture planes are coincident will be sites of hydrothermal alteration and potential gold targets. Base metal mineralization is normally likely to occur in relation to specific lithologies and stratigraphic units associated with sulphides within sedimentary, mafic and volcanic rock units common to the Doolgunna and Maraloou Formations.

event_text: A review of the Melville Deposit was completed by Orelogy, Perth in April-May 2008 to ascertain the current value of the resource. Pit Optimisation utilising Whittle 4D and a Sensitivity Analysis utilising current mining and process costs, recoveries and various gold prices were completed. A number of optimisation runs were examined with the base case results showing that even though the gold price has increased from US$500/oz to US$650/oz (since the last optimisation in 2005), the mining and processing costs impact significantly on the value of the project. Including inferred ore had a minimal effect on the size and value of the optimal pit. Sensitivity analysis was undertaken by increasing process and mining costs, reducing process recovery by 10%, increasing gold price, reducing overall slopes and including inferred ore.

event_text: The Meentheena Project region is dominated by two granitoid batholiths, the Yilgalong (within and marginal to tenure) and the Mt Edgar further to the west (Figures 1). Major structures have been recorded by regional mapping (GSWA) of which several N-S fault zones are proving of significant interest. In the East Pilbara, the N-S Meentheena fault zone is a crustal scale suture and at the prospect level it has sub-parallel components such as the Big Ridge Fault Zone that has been a major metasomatising structure. event_text: Gold production from this area is recorded as approximately 1363 kg from 43,043 tonnes at an average grade of 31.67g/t Au. The gold is associated with boudinaged quartz veins with anastomosing shear zones hosted within pyritic sericite chlorite schists with felspar porphyry dykes occurring within the shear zones. The Yarri mining centre includes several mineralised structures and quartz reefs in east dipping shear structures within the Yarri Monzogranodiorite and along the basalt/monzonite contact. Historic production in the region includes 695kg of gold from 45,559 tonnes at a grade of 15.3g/t Au whilst in more recent times mining in the 1940s and late 1980s at the Porphyry and Million dollar pits totalled 4446 kg of gold from 1.3 million tonnes at a grade of 3.42 g/t Au. Historic gold production at the Edjudina Mining Centre, 6 km SE of the tenement, of 33,215 oz @ 46.9 g/t of gold was recorded, sourced from contiguous underground mines developed on series of sub-parallel quartz lodes over a strike length of 1.4 kilometres between 1898 and 1939.

event_text: Regional tectonism and granite emplacement has resulted in strong tilting of the greenstonemetasediment sequence, typically dipping 60-80 to the north with subsequent thrust faulting, and possible sequence repetition locally. Outcrop exposure is generally very good with the exception of heavy, tallus scree slopes on some of the prominent chert ridges and the 8-Mile Creek drainage system that run through the project area. Regional metamorphism in the project area is generally low grade, except adjacent to granitiod complexes, where it has reached lower amphibolite facies. The Muccan Granitiod Complex (MGC) is situated to the immediate north of the project area and is expressed as a flat expanse of well-drained spinifex plain. The southern contact of this complex is intrusive into a greenstone and meta-sediment sequence of rocks and appears knife-like.

event_text: Considering data available, the tenement has immediate potential for two types of mineral prospectivity; uranium in calcrete / vein style and rare earth elements (REEs) in eluvial style deposits that have been weathered out of pegmatite dykes. Uranium is a major mineral of interest in the area and much exploration occurred in the 1970s for calcrete style deposits. It is now believed that vein style mineralisation associated with the numerous pegmatites in the area could provide the most potential. The uranium source is likely from the regional basement augen gneiss which has above average background radiation levels. This gniess has been metamorphosed into the Morrissey suite migmatite and has two pegmatite belts to the north and south.

event_text: A mineralised high level epithermal field (~20 km2 mapped) has been recognised in late Archaean to Fortescue Group rocks via collective geological, structural, geochemical features. This field was emplaced into part of the Warrawoona rocks, although principally into and syn the Mt Roe Basalt and lessor into the overlying Hardey Formation volcanosediments with evidence of minor reactivation well up into the Kylena Formation. Geochemically the system is variably anomalous in Au-Ag-As-Hg-Sb-W-Mo-Se and lessor Cu-Pb. Hydrothermal mineralisation in veins and breccias is dominated by silica (multiple textures including dominantly chalcedonic/opaline, micro crystalline quartz, banded colloform silica and quartz pseudomorphing platy calcite), extensive chlorite, sericite, some kaolin and carbonate alteration with significant sulphide in breccia veins (mainly pyrite, possibly arsenical pyrite). Geochemical data has been processed by Carras Mining to determine assay relationships between samples thereby allowing sample grouping (based on geochemical features) and then assessment of anomalism within those individual groups.

event_text: Tenement Area (blocks) Grant Expiry Commitment Rent Registered holder E80/3465 44 22.08.06 21.08.11 $44,000.00 $4,844.84 NADL 4.0 Geology The licence is located within the North Australian Craton, which is described as a stable block of deformed and metamorphosed Palaeoproterozoic age rocks. The Kimberley Basin forms the platform cover to the craton and consists of a succession of sedimentary and volcanics rocks of Proterozoic age. The terrain formed by the Kimberley Basin is rugged and is essentially a broad plateau dissected by strong jointing that has resulted in a well developed drainage system. The oldest unit that crops out within the licence is the Warton Sandstone which is a white quartz sandstone heavily dissected by jointing. The Carson Volcanics conformably underly the Warton Sandstone and may be exposed within the licence.

event_text: The region falls within the Edjudina Terrane (Swager et al., 1990) of the Eastern Goldfields Province and is bound by the Claypan fault to the west and the Pinjin fault to the east. This region differs from the domains to the west with minor volumes of metabasalt and metakomatiite and more prolific calc-alkaline andesitic complexes with associated clastic rocks as well as BIF, chert and metasedimentary sequences intruded by metadolerite (Swager,1995a,1997). The region has undergone greenschist metamorphism although high grades upto amphibolite can occur close to granite margins. Locally the geology consists of intermediate schists and sediments with BIF forming prominent north west trending ridges. The basaltic schists tend to form more flat to gently undulating landforms and shallow surficial sediments cover most of the region and outcrop is limited.

event_text: 4.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY AND MINERALISATION There is no exposed geology in the Top Well project area but the regional setting consists of Archaean granite domes containing remnant greenstone xenoliths and roof pendants, representing attenuating remnants of a northern extension of the east limb of the Mt Ida greenstone belt. Dead Camel Hill to the south of the project area is one such remnant which was explored by CRA Exploration in 1995, who reported narrow komatiitic units within the belt. At present encouraging nickel and copper intersections are being reported by Western Areas NL at their Mt Alexander Joint Venture area situated some 25 km to the southwest. event_text: The maximum extent Page 7 of 15 November 2006 these folds could be traced as a distinct feature was about 50 m down the hinge and along the plunge. A major F3 synform trending towards 340 and plunging 50-75 towards 350 comprises the Koolanooka Synform described by Baxter and Lipple (1979 & 1985). This synform is asymmetric due to more extensive granitoid emplacement on the eastern limb. Open to tight folds (F4) with an associated mineral cleavage (S4) in pelitic rocks and BIF, and spaced fracture cleavage in sandstone plunge 50-75 towards the southwest (220-250). These structures probably correlate with the "mild concentric buckling with moderate southwesterly plunge and an intersection lineation of spaced cleavage on bedding" recorded by Baxter and Lipple (1979).

event_text: The Duffer Formation, which extends over 18km of strike in E45/2578, is a recognised host for base metals mineralisation for these deposits. At Lennons Find a group of stratiform bodies bearing Zn, Cu, Pb and Ag lies in sheared sericite schists, calc-silicate rocks, and metamorphosed felsic volcanic rocks of the upper part of the Duffer Formation (cyclic mafic to metavolcanic rocks) of the Warrawoona Group (GSWA Report 81, p. 66). The main mineralised zone extends 4.3km and the bodies are typically Zn, Pb and Ba rich at the top and Zn and Cu rich at the base. The Hammerhead Prospect has been reported as an Indicated Resource of 1.2 mt at 7.7% zinc, 0.43% copper, 1.94% lead and 100g/t silver (under 1988 Australian Code for Reporting Resources and Reserves). Centenary Mining subsequently defined an inferred resource of 4.2mt in extensions of Hammerhead and in other on-strike mineralised zones.

event_text: This fault is a major structure, estimated to extend in a northerly direction for some 150 km. event_text: A summary of exploration is presented on Figure 2. Gold mineralisation within the Davyhurst area is associated with two spatially separate and geologically distinct zones, designated by Hellsten et al (1990) as the Western and Eastern Sequences. Mineralisation within the Eastern Sequence is typically marked by sulphide mineralisation associated with thin (<30 metre thick), broadly folded biotite- actinolite-carbonate schist hosted within massive amphibolite. Deposits of this nature include Great Ophir, Lights of Israel and Golden Eagle (Norum, 2007a). Mineralisation within the Western Sequence is hosted by highly strained units of foliated to banded dolerite and chlorite-tremolite schists within competent blocks of basalt.

event_text: Soil structure can be influenced by the particle size distribution, chemical composition and organic matter content of a soil, and is often affected by root growth, vehicle compaction, and with respect to reconstructed soil profiles, the methods of soil handling and deposition. When a soil material is disturbed, the breakdown of aggregates into primary particles can lead to structural decline (Needham et al., 1998). This can result in hard-setting and crusting at the soil surface and a massive soil structure at depth, potentially reducing the ability of seeds to germinate, roots to penetrate the soil matrix and water to infiltrate to the root zone. Observations and assessment of soil structure were made at all surface soil survey sites within the three Project areas. Soil structure in profiles at Mertondale and Raeside was similar, with well structured, friable topsoil of moderate to strong aggregates in the upper surface horizons, occasionally increasing in consistence with depth above the hardpan.

event_text: It contains the oldest ore deposit known in the world (a barite deposit with an age of around 3490 Ma). In the West Pilbara terrain the oldest known mineralization is the Ruth Well komatiite-associated Ni-Cu deposit which is hosted by the Ruth Well Formation, the oldest rock sequence of the Roebourne Group of greenstones with an age in excess of 3270 Ma. The 3120 Ma Whundo Group hosts several VMS deposits of which the largest, the Whundo deposit, has been partially mined in the mid seventies. The most significant mineralizing event in the West Pilbara terrain was the intrusion of large layered intrusions at 2920-2900 Ma.

event_text: On 21 November 2013 IGO withdrew from the agreement. 4.0 GEOLOGY AND MINERALISATION 4.1 Regional Geology The Eastern Goldfield Province occupies the eastern third of the Yilgarn Craton. It is a typical Archaean granite-greenstone terrain characterised by large areas of granitoid and broad to narrow, linear and arcuate belts of greenstone. The greenstones are deformed and metamorphosed to greenschist facies or higher and comprise thick mafic to ultramafic volcanic sequences and intrusives, felsic and intermediate volcanic sequences pelitic and psammitic sedimentary sequences and inter-bedded chert, banded iron formation and shale. Granitoid intrusions and regional deformation involving multiple episodes of folding and strike faulting have disrupted the greenstone sequences.

There is a very strong structural control to the Archaean lode gold deposits of the Pilbara Craton, with most being related to regional fault systems. The gold mineralisation usually occurs at the contact between quartz vein stockworks and brittle fractured wall-rocks. Most of the ore in these deposits is finely disseminated, with gold generally being invisible to the naked eye. Much of the gold mineralization across the Pilbara Craton appears to have been syntectonic rather than post-tectonic, with late-stage high-level gold mineralization events associated with shear zones and normal faults.

event_text: Mapping by GSWA has led to definition of the Glengarry Basin (Gee, 1979 & 1987, and Gee & Grey, 1993) which has more recently been subdivided into the Yerrida, Bryah and Padbury Basins (Pirajno et al., 1998 & 2000). Due to the complex structural framework, combined with cover obscuring many areas, it is considered that further revision of the stratigraphy of the area will take place as more information becomes available. The region has a history of copper production at Thaduna from epigenetic, fault-related mineralisation, and gold production further to the west at the Peak Hill mining centre where epigenetic gold in quartz reefs were exploited. The Horseshoe Lights copper-gold mine, located in the north-western part of the Bryah Basin has produced some 300,000 oz gold and 50,000t copper. The mineralisation is hosted within felsic schist of the Narracoota Volcanics and comprises massive, disseminated and stringer sulphides with a Cu-Au-Ag-Pb-Zn association, with GSWA interpreting the deposit as volcanogenic massive sulphide (VMS) style.

Lode-gold deposits may form in any lithology (Figure 6) within a greenstone belt, however spatial analysis suggests preferences (Groves 1990). Rheological factors are important, as a brittle material is more likely to localise fluid flow and thus allow mineralization. Chemical composition also plays a role, with Fe or Fe-+Mg rich rocks capable of destabilizing gold complexes precipitating Fe sulphides and gold. event_text: Conclusions: Drilling completed at the Minnie Springs prospect has successfully confirmed the grade and thickness of Mo Cu W mineralisation as intersected within prior RC drilling plus increasing the continuity of mineralisation over a 700m strike length with widths and depths respectively of up to 100m and 150m. Mineralisation is dominantly vein related and interpreted as having formed during late stage magmatic hydrothermal activity associated with syntectonic emplacement of a multi-phased intrusive. Regional exploration completed outside of the Minnie Springs prospect area has successfully delineated new areas of elevated Mo W Sn and W respectively at the Hidden Valley and Nina prospects. Newly identified areas provide testament that regional parts of the project contain considerable potential for additional granite hosted discoveries such as that identified at the Minnie Springs deposit to be uncovered. Additionally, newly re-viewed/acquired radiometric data has demonstrated that new style of mineralisation, such as primary and/or secondary style uranium may also be present throughout the project area.

event_text: The Red Eye project area represents an opportunity for new mineralisation models to be applied to the typically orogenic/shear zone focused exploration targeting within the Kalgoorlie Terrane. Field reconnaissance has led to the identification of USTs and miarolitic cavities at the carapace zone of the Scotia Dome (Figure 3). These are typical indicators of a magmatic-hydrothermal transitional environment which is conducive for hydrostatic failure, brecciation and associated mineralisation (Doran, 2013). A number of deposit types are characteristically hosted within these settings including Porphyry Cu-Mo-Au, Intrusion Related Gold Deposits (IRGD), Granitoid-Hosted Au and Skarn W-Mo-Au The Timbarra gold deposit in New South Wales can be used as an analogue for IRGD-type mineralisation. Timbarra is a Triassic aged, disseminated gold system containing ~400 Koz total resources within several ore bodies hosted within the carapace zone of a monzogranite (Mustard, 2001).

event_text: The preservation of chert mesolayers within zones of hematite alteration suggests that these jaspilite occurrences essentially represent domains that were exposed to the same, second-stage hypogene fluid that precipitated hematite in the orebodies at Windarling. However, in contrast, these more peripheral hematitic alteration domains lacked the earlier hypogene dolomite alteration and were therefore not subject to the same level of iron-oxide concentration that accompanied the leaching of dolomite. The other line of field evidence that points to the formation of jaspilite during the second-stage hypogene hydrothermal event (that formed iron-ore mineralisation) is the presence of massive to irregular bodies of red and translucent chalcedony within some jaspilite units. These jasperoid bodies display transitional or diffuse boundaries with the host jaspilite units, and may be up to 50 m long and extend across strike for up to 20 m. Chalcedony takes the form of diffuse replacement zones and more distinct dilational veins. The veins appear to have formed during a progressive hydrothermal event, during which early hematitic chalcedonic replacement zones or veins are cross-cut or replaced by later barren white chalcedony.

event_text: One possible explanation for this involves the infiltration of an Fe-rich melt into the main cumulus crystal pile and its cooling as an intercumulus melt in the crystal pile. This leads to a major shift in Fo in these olivines to lower Fo values (a process very well documented in cumulate assemblages from numerous layered intrusions; Irvine 1980; Naslund 1984) with little or no change in their Ni content, because of the far higher olivine-Ni KD (partition coefficient) with decreasing temperature (KD = 7-8 at 1250C and increases to ~20 at 1100C: Li and Ripley, 2010). If the residual melt achieved sulphide saturation, then the sulphides that crystallized would be significantly more Ni-poor and Cu-rich than magmatic sulphides formed from parental basaltic magmas. This is in keeping with the observation that the dominant sulphide at the Navigator Prospect, albeit in very small amounts, is chalcopyrite. In this model, the Fe-rich residual melts percolating down may become relatively more Ni-rich by dissolving any interstitial sulphides encountered as they do so, as S capacity at sulphide saturation increases significantly as melt Fe contents increase.

event_text: Warrawoona Stage (3525 3420 Ma) is the oldest event and involved the eruption of the Warrawoona Group volcanic rocks and emplacement of granitic rocks of the Callina and Tambina Supersuites. Two periods of deformation and contact-style metamorphism also occurred during this stage. The second formational event, Kelly Stage (3350 3290 Ma), involved the deposition of Kelly Group volcanic rocks, emplacement of the Emu Pool Supersuite and an interval of substantial deformation and metamorphism. The final Sulpur Springs Stage (3275 -3225 Ma) encompassed deposition of the Sulphur Springs Group, emplacement of the Cleland Supersuite and another major period of deformation and metamorphism. The GSWA interpreted bedrock geology of the project area is shown on Figure 2.

event_text: The key is to understand the possible proxies in available datasets that represent these processes. By using a systems approach the explorer is no longer dependent upon the influence of only one particular component of orebody formation, such as structure. In this study Optiro focused on the mineral system model outlined by the Predictive Mineral Discovery * Cooperative Research Centre, which seeks to answer five questions as to why an orebody is where it is. These questions relate to the geodynamics, architecture and structure, fluid reservoirs (source), the fluid flow drivers and pathways and depositional mechanisms (Figure 5.1). This method of exploration has been successfully applied in the Yilgarn and other gold orogenic belts and has led to the prediction and discovery of multiple million-ounce deposits.

event_text: (Seymour, D.B et al, 1988; Powell, C. & Horwitz, R.C 1994) Powell and Horwitz (1994) proposes the subdivision of the Wyloo Group into upper and lower sub-groups based on the presence of a distinct unconformable geological boundary separating the two groups resulting from tectonic activity in the formation of the Ashburton Trough (i.e. Mount McGrath Formation unconformable overlies the Duck Creek Dolomite.) This hypothesis is supported by the locality of deposition of the sediments that comprise both the lower and upper Wyloo Groups. Sediments belonging to both the lower and upper Wyloo Groups are present only within the Mount McGrath and Ashburton Trough respectively. This geological unconformity that separates the Wyloo Group into separate upper and lower subgroups was created during the down faulting and subsidence at the latter parts of the lower Wyloo Group sedimentation in the Mount McGrath Trough, resulting from lateral tectonic extensions and the formation of the Ashburton trough.

event_text: The structural deformation events within the project area have been adequately described in the GSWA 1:100,000 Geological Series explanatory notes (Reganti & Chen 2002 and Wyche et al. Local Structure The prominent structural features of the district includes a large NW-SE trending basin to the south, occupied by the Marda Complex and associated granitoids, and the SSW plunging Diemals Anticline in the northwest. Both features are separated by a series of extensive northeast trending faults with an interpreted dextral movement of 18 to 25km. The areas between these faults are highly deformed and are strongly influenced by the intrusive diapiric Pigeon Rocks medium grained monzogranite and subsequent movement along the major bounding faults. event_text: Within the plasmic clay zone may be zones of silcrete and iron rich hardpan of silcrete thickness. Underlying the plasmic clays are saprolitic clays with occasional silcrete bands up to 5-6 metre thick. The saprolites, where not mineralised with nickel and cobalt, are usually iron rich (limonitic, haematitic and goethitic). The economic nickel\cobalt occurs within the saprolitic clay zones, generally a few metres below the boundary between the overlying plasmic clays and the underlying saprolitic clays. Much of the potential mineralisation is found within grey\brown or dark grey saprolites, but frequently high grade material is found within goethitic\haematitic saprolites or within siliceous pale grey saprolites.

event_text: Mylonitic fabrics in pegmatite dykes that surround the 2838 6 Ma Bonney Downs Granite (which in part abuts the southern margin of the Mosquito Creek Belt), suggests that regional shearing continued in this part of the Pilbara Craton until at least ca 2840 Ma. Mapping by company geologists in 2005 show that the mafic-ultramafic rocks in most cases appear to be juxtaposed against sedimentary rock units by faults. It is proposed here that there may be only one sedimentary formation within the Mosquito Creek Belt, and that the thin units of mafic-ultramafic rocks may represent fault-imbricated slices of a volcanic basin floor upon which the sedimentary rock were deposited (probably as a prograding submarine fan system). This mapping also supports an interpretation that the Mosquito Creek Formation can be subdivided into two parts; the upper part characterised by interlayered shale, siltstone and thinly bedded, fine to mediumgrained sandstone, and the lower part containing a greater abundance of 1 to 10 mthick coarse-grained sandstone and conglomerate beds (interlayered with shale, siltstone and fine to medium-grained sandstone). Gold mineralisation in the Mosquito Creek Belt exhibits strong structural and lithological controls, from the regional scale through to the outcrop scale.
label: False

event_text: Regionally the granite and gneiss domes display a weak northeasterly trending metamorphic foliation. Page | 4 The granitoids which post-date the gneiss also transect the early foliation of the greenstone belts, and bear no protoclastic fabric. It is possible that these granitoids were generated during the doming of the gneiss, and subsequently intruded the greenstone belts and gneiss. The dome structure has been greatly modified by intense deformation which produced north-north-westerly trending belts of strongly granulated and mylonitized rock. Second generation formation is considered to be synchronous with the formation of these zones, and resulting in folding and crenulation of the earlier metamorphic fabric.

event_text: Gold mineralisation in the Meekatharra-Wydgee Greenstone Belt occurs in most of the Archean lithologies listed, often close to inferred major shear zones and appears to be largely localised in generally steeply-dipping contact zones between felsic porphyry intrusives and ultramafic and mafic volcanics/intrusives. The mineralization can be considered mesothermal, shear zone hosted in style, being associated with quartz-pyrite veins, veinsets and stockworking and variable carbonate-fuchsitesericite-biotite alteration assemblages. Clearly supergene gold mineralisation also occurs, notably in the Bluebird East and adjacent deposit areas in the Bluebird Gold Camp to the south of the Highway of the northeastern Murchison Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton (Figure 2). The multi-element analyses of the MAGLAG samples has effectively defined areas that require follow-up either by additional sampling, auger geochemical sampling or RAB/air core drilling. The wide spaced initial MAGLAG programme strongly supports the need for infill MAGLAG sampling on traverses 200 m apart and sample stations initially of 80 m (with the potential to close down to 40 m).

event_text: The distribution, composition, thickness and areal extent of these deposits are the result of interacting depositional and erosional controls related to climate, parent rocks, drainage, topography and vegetation (Hickman, Smurthwaite, Brown and Davy, 1992). 3.2 Historical Exploration The existence of bauxite in the Darling Range was established early last century but exploration by a commercial entity did not commence until the late 1950s. Significant bauxite laterite deposits were discovered in the Darkling Range by Western Mining Corporation in 1957. The deposits were deemed economically viable and WMC established a joint venture called Western Aluminium No Liability (WANL) and a special mining lease covering an area of 12,619km2 of mainly forested Crown land was granted in 1961. Scout drilling and sampling of the duricrust revealed significant deposits in the Jarrahdale-Dwellingup region to the south-east of Perth, which were later exploited after Aluminium Company of America (Alcoa) joined the WANL venture to become Alcoa World Alumina Australia in 1977.

event_text: The target horizon considered prospective for Broken Hill Style lead-zinc mineralisation was the Lower Proterozoic Morrissey Metamorphics. This unit consists of schist, phyllite, quartzite, micaceous quartzite and thick sequences of quartzo-feldspathic paragneiss. The Morrissey Metamorphics is a metamorphosed sequence of shale, siltstone, sandstone, greywacke, arkose and conglomerate, with extensive migmatite development. Small amphibolite and calc-silicate bodies derived from basalt and carbonate sediments respectively also occur within the sequence. The Morrissey Metamorphics were intruded by early stage gneissic granitoids during or just after peak metamorphism.

event_text: Three ultramafic units are recognised in the Emily Ann Maggie Hays area; the Western Ultramafic (WUU), the Central Ultramafic (CUU) and the Eastern Ultramafic (EUU). The CUU is the thickest and contains a succession of ultramafic differentiates with basal olivine peridotite which is a typical host for nickel sulphide mineralisation. The EUU consists of thin discontinuous volcanic flows and may also host minor nickel sulphide mineralisation. The WUU is thicker and more persistent than the EUU and typical nickel sulphide host rock types have been identified. The stratigraphic relationships between the three ultramafics are not certain because of the early thrust faulting.

event_text: The Tertiary palaeochannels of the Lake Raeside project areas may have the potential to host roll-front uranium deposits such as those in the Gawler Craton of South Australia. The combination of uraniferous source rocks and potential trap sites could make the Lake Raeside palaeochannels prospective exploration targets for roll-front uranium. Carbonate is often formed when organic matter is oxidised and any uranium associated with it can be deposited as calcrete. event_text: The Laverton Domain sequence may represent autochthonous basement to the younger rock units in the Edjudina and Linden Domains. The Duketon Domain of the Burtville Terrane includes c. 2810Ma intermediate and felsic volcanic rocks and associated maficultramafic rocks in the central and eastern parts of the Duketon Greenstone Belt as well as greenstone assemblages dominated by mafic and ultramafic volcanic and fine-grained sedimentary rocks. A modification of this tectonic subdivision was proposed by Pawley et al (2012) based on remapping, new geophysical, isotopic and geochemical data. These authors subdivided the former Burtville Terrane into the redefined older Burtville Terrane, which includes the former Duketon and Merolia domains, and the newly recognized younger Yarmana Terrane. The Hootanui Fault separates the Kurnalpi and Burtville Terranes, while the Burtville and Yarmarna Terranes are separated by the Yarmana Shear Zone.

event_text: Massive sulphide bodies are usually fairly narrow and of short strike length, and they are often highly conductive. If sufficient pyrrhotite or magnetite is present, a magnetic anomaly may be associated with the EM anomaly. Stratiform deposits, however, commonly contain disseminated sulphide mineralisation, and electromagnetic responses over such bodies may be diffuse to almost non-existent. Strike length can be considerable in the case of stratiform deposits, and magnetic signatures, if any, tend to parallel the trend of the regional geology. SPECTREM EM anomalies are graded A, B, C or D, with grade A anomalies being the most favorable.

event_text: The mineralised komatiites of interest to this study lie in the UG, a narrow (5 km wide in the Mt Keith-Six Mile Well area), elongate (240 km long) belt that strikes NNW, dips W and is dominantly W facing. The stratigraphy for the UG is poorly understood, comprising of volcanic and volcanoclastic rocks (acid, felsic & mafic), sedimentary rocks (pelites, shales and cherts), basalts (pillowed, tholeiitic and high Mg) and komatiite sequences (olivine ad-mesoorthocumulates and thin spinifex textured flows). The olivine adcumulates, host to Type 2 NiS mineralisation are the thicker lenticular part of the komatiitic sequences and were originally interpreted as intrusive dykes, (e.g., Burt and Sheppy, 1975; Binns et al., 1977, 1982; Groves and Keays, 1979; Marston et al., 1981), sill-like feeder chambers for the overlying spinifex-textured komatiites (Naldrett and Turner, 1977; Lesher and Groves, 1986) or ponded lava lakes (Donaldson et al., 1986). However, a more recent interpretation indicates that these komatiites formed as channelized flows (Barnes et al., 1988c; Hill et al., 1990b, 1995; Dowling and Hill, 1990). These sequences are overlain by the E-facing Jones Creek Conglomerate, the basal contact of which represents a major Archan unconformity (Durney, 1972; Marston and Travis, 1976), dated at 2.695 Ga 0.015 (Rb-Sr total rock age; Roddick et al., 1976).

event_text: In the area of Pincher Hill, felsic metasedimentary and volcanic rocks of the Pincher Well Complex dominate. In the far south, the geology consists of narrow bands of mafics and ultramafics, bound and intercalated by granites. Numerous gold prospects have been identified. These include the Specking Patch, Currans and Currans South within the lower mafic dominated portion of the greenstone succession, the majority of which are believed to be associated with splay structures propagating off the Youanmi Fault Zone. The Pincher Well, North Dome, Hannans, Superior and Bohemia gold prospects lie within the upper felsic volcano-sedimentary succession dominating the western portion of the Pincher Hill tenement block, and are largely associated with gossanous sulphidic BIF horizons.

event_text: This survey also delineates some additional BIF units that appear to be subcropping. 2.1.2 Structure (after Stewart & Whitfield, 1971) The entire Jack Hills Range represents to be a synclinorium of Archaean aged rocks, preserved as a roof pendant in the gneiss complex. The synclinorium appears to plunge south-westerly at the northeast end of the range and possibly to the northeast in the southwest of the range (Noonie Hills Sector). The synclinorium is thought to reach its maximum width in the Mt Matthew - Mt Hale vicinity, where proposed mining is to take place. This area coincides with the highest elevation, the most complex structural parameters and the major occurrences of iron mineralisation.

event_text: The mapping defines a series of fine to coarse grained mafics on the western flank, which underlie the first major breakaway clearly visible to the left upon driving around the western side of Redcliffe. Mapping includes the breakaway structures and has shown significant parallel swarms of weakly sulphidic vertical quartz veining within weathered indurated well-sheared mafics. This mafic series continues across approximately to the 330 trending midline of the Redcliffe pit where it is agreed that mineralisation propagates partly within sulphidic quartz veins and partly within strongly sheared sericitised mafic-felsic contact schist and mylonite. Surface geology in outcrop reveals that the same mafic lithologies may appear as fresh to partly weathered in some locations and also moderately to strongly weathered in the greater of proportions as purple-brown-tan-crme patchings, such that comparison for detail and similarity is difficult to impossible. Another observation is that a 060-240 degree trend band of thicker and more clustered quartz veins occurs, the veins are still parallel and sub parallel to geology and striking at ~330-150, but have perhaps been injected as a distinct band across the geology during expansion and extension.

event_text: These surfaces have subsequently been eroded by the existing drainage system, often preserving remnants of the Hamersley surfaces in mesas. 3.2 Structure The Hamersley Province has undergone a complex deformation history, with at least five deformation events (D1-D5) recognised, as follows: D 1 is indicated by layer-parallel isoclinal folds and boudinage of chert and BIF horizons. The event is widespread but does not disrupt stratigraphy significantly. The structures are interpreted to have developed because of extension and compaction within the early basin. Mount Elvire Project Annual Technical Report E47/1256 D 2 (Ophthalmia Orogeny) was the most significant event to affect the Province.

event_text: The tenements were acquired primarily as high potential targets for concealed channel iron deposits (CID) as they are located upstream of the Marillana paleochannel that hosts the Yandicogina CID operations of both BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. Secondary exploration targets were bedded iron (BID) and detrital iron (DID) deposits hosted or derived from the Brockman Iron Formation. Geological mapping at 1:25,000 scale was carried out over all of the tenements but only identified small outcrops of martite goethite mineralisation in the Joffre Member of the Brockman Iron Formation with even smaller areas of associated detrital mineralisation and canga. These outcropping areas were unable to be drill tested because of the inability to obtain approval from the Banjima traditional owners (as well as the steep terrain). event_text: Correlation between counts per second (cps) and uranium abundance depends on the age of the mineralisation and radiometric equilibrium. Uranium carried in solution and precipitated in recent surface deposits is normally classed as young and is not likely to be in radiogenic equilibrium with its daughter products that produce the measured radiometric signature. This means that the cps rate measured from a young uranium deposit might be significantly lower than expected and not reflect the true abundance of uranium at the site being measured. Holes were drilled using a reverse circulation air-core system and were logged using a down hole spectrometer. Water samples were collected.

event_text: VALE INCO Australia Limited Partnership, Goongarrie Project 2008 Annual Report Page 29 of 32 . 6.0 Conclusions and Recommendations Exploration activities conducted on the Goongarrie Project tenements during the reporting period were completed by VIALP in order to fulfil farm-in agreement commitments and focused on the completion of works integral to the completion of the Step 3 Pre-feasibility study on the Kalgoorlie Nickel Project (KNP) as a whole. These works included a review of calcrete occurrences in historic RC drilling, the completion of geophysical resistivity surveys at Goongarrie South and Goongarrie Hill prospects, resource infill drilling, water exploration drilling, and sonic drilling to obtain bulk samples for metallurgical testing. In total, 861 RC holes for 42,919m and 52 Sonic holes for 2551.45m, were drilled within the Goongarrie combined reporting project during the 2008 calendar year. In addition 5 water bores for 377.3m were drilled to obtain baseline hydrogeological data.

event_text: While further exploration for nickel has been conducted since the early 1970s and a best result of 3m @ 3.05% Ni was intersected in a 1998 Bundarra Holdings Pty Ltd RC hole, an economic nickel accumulation is yet to be discovered. The nearest economic nickel deposit is located approximately 24km to the northeast of the Spargos prospect at the Nepean nickel mine, which is at the southern end of the Coolgardie greenstone belt and was discovered by Metals Exploration NL in 1968. Twelve RC holes for a total of 2,933 metres were completed at the Benari Prospect on E15/913 (Figure 7). The drill programme was designed to test MLEM QVR_C98/2004_2013S Page 15 anomalies which were coincident with historical VTEM anomalies and geochemical (nickel and copper) anomalies. The drilling intersected the defined MLTEM conductors but most were found to be sulphidic sediments, however, ultramafic lithologies were confirmed in some holes.

event_text: A series of gold prospects in the McPhee Formation in the Marble Bar greenstone belt includes some that are currently being exploited through alluvial mining. The Little Las Vegas to the east of the Talga River has quite low reported values of anomalous gold. The main group of six prospects, however, are located just west of the Talga River (Van Kranendonk, 2010). Disaggregated pods of massive chromite in serpentinised peridotite in the Doolena Gap greenstone belt originally formed seams and layers in the peridotite host rock. The host rocks represent either intrusive sills or the lower cumulate parts of thick volcanic flows, but the deformation state is typically too high in this region to discriminate between these two options, and mineral compositional work has not been carried out.

event_text: Documentation and evidence for systematic exploration carried out in the area is poor. Soil samples were typically collected at a spacing of 200 m by 50 m while RAB drilling was generally along 160 m or 320 m spaced traverses. event_text: Comprehensive reviews of historical data highlighted a zone of anomalous nickel and copper in the Christchurch Dam area (located at the centre of the northern portion of E28/1383), which was confirmed by Heron using a Niton XRF survey. EM surveys were conducted to pick up sulphide stringers. Diamond hole ADDD0002 intercepted massive sulphide stringers between 60 and 65 m depth with a maximum assay result of 0.12 m @ 0.97% Ni, 0.23% Cu and 1,207 ppb Pt+Pd from 62.49 to 62.61 m. Trace disseminated sulphides were encountered in ADDD0001 and ADDD0003 but did not return significant results. A representative cross-section for the Christchurch Dam prospect is provided in Figure 9. Petrographical analysis of diamond core samples showed that the majority of the sulphides were remobilised except in minor basaltic dykes which contain possible former primary magmatic Fe NiCu sulphides.
